Text.Value: What makes you any better? The vast swathes butchered in your wake?
Common killers? Bhaal ought not consort with anyone but his own elect Spawn.
Perhaps you shall soon receive what you most desire.
But it wanes compared to the first. I have spent much time contemplating this.
Welcome, Unholy Assassin. You stand among common killers, children of Murder, and would-be gods. Auspicious company indeed.
Why would Bhaal keep around one of his foes?
One night, in thousands of years, you shall watch the stars collapse in the heavens in each other's arms, and be broiled to the bone.
The Bhaalists made a memorial of your death.
Bhaal should not consort with common murderers. They're beneath him.
It was known to those who walked this path before you - common killers, children of Murder, and would-be gods. And now it is known to you.
For devotees of death, you of his line are so basely fascinated with propagating new life. It ever seemed to me an impurity in the doctrine.
You have found your way to the Murder Tribunal - Bhaal's favour is yours to grasp.
You are mistaken. I would be the one to eat you.
Every kill is euphoria.
To kill once is to taste godhood. Every kill thereafter is an attempt to sup that ecstasy again.
When I am the last man alive in a dead world, then I will slit my own throat.
When I am the last woman alive in a dead world, then I will slit my own throat.
When I am the last creature alive in a dead world, then I will slit my own throat.
Leave me, little Bhaal-stain. Cast your perversions elsewhere, while I meditate on pure, perfect, death.
Bhaal seems to attract a lot of usurpers as followers.
Go, Unholy Assassin. Walk in blood, enjoy Bhaal's favour. But never lose sight of that first, perfect murder.
I tricked the first, devoured the second - all in pursuit of the third. Godhood.
Tell me, Bhaalspawn. How do you wish to die?
Of old age, with my loved ones all around me, in bed.
I spent my life preparing for myself a death that none could look away from. The very Gods, ALL OF THEM, were forced to watch my fall at the Mana Forge.
I am Amelyssan the Blackhearted. I stood as Bhaal's high priestess - his eternal succour. Until I sought to usurp him.
It's not something I think about.
You reek of his blood. You snivel here looking for scab-scrapings of his favour. Snivel well, murder-whelp.
It will be in Father's Temple, with him watching.
To die among the stars, in the Astral Plane. It was a fine death. Perhaps the best.
The Lord of Murder did not take kindly to betrayal.
You mock death? Know that somewhere in the filthy air you breathe, Lord Bhaal is always laughing. And he laughs at you.
Then Lord Bhaal shall claim what was long overdue.
Tell me - do any of them feel as good as your first kill?
A mere crime of passion. You must kill without prejudice, without distinction, without reason. Death without motive is truth.
I know my place. I have spent much time pondering it.
You should hope for a fraction of the honour.
Learn this, and you may yet strive for such heightened deaths as mine.

EditorData.NodeContext: smug - her death was incredibly flashy

Text.Value: I consumed many Bhaalspawn in my life, their essence my spellfodder. If I lived yet, you would be eaten.
So which are you? Common killer, child of Murder, or would-be god?
A sorry thing, there will be no audience left for your finale.
You are learning it takes more than birth-blood alone to become a consecrated killer. It takes belief.
'His eternal succour'? Did you graft Spawn with him?
You are all blood-blind butchers, and have forgotten how to meditate on your murders.
Ah - but a tool to what end?
How romantic.
I wish you good slaughter, Unholy Assassin. Delight in it - while you still can.
Such a question Sarevok must ask me thrice a year. He deludes himself with suspicions of living Spawn from my womb. There are none.
You know there is no being alive Bhaal will not claim. The ultimate victory in his war is to strike the last killing blow ever to be struck.
I don't care for your questions.
My favourite kill was that of mine own dearest.
I need not. My beloved has the key to immortality.
And now you're a ghost who lives under a tombstone shop.
Every time you kill, every time a life gives up in disgrace afore your eyes, you must imagine how you will die better.
Hail, Unholy Assassin. You have fulfilled a fraction of your blood's dark promise.
No. Nothing compares.
I take no pleasure in killing. It is merely a tool.
Leave.
Ambition is our curse. We have no choice - murder begets it. Always.
I'm guessing the challenge met with failure.
Does that make you a victim of such slaughter?
You really are the most perfect of his children yet born.
Sarevok and the tainted faithful see it as an honour to serve Bhaal even in death. He knows to me, it is a slave-sentence.
Exactly. That is why our ambition kills us all, in the end.
It was my triumph to die among the stars, in the Astral Plane. It was a fine death. Perhaps the best.
Arrogant indeed. Very well - walk in blood, Unholy Assassin. But tread lightly.

Synopsis: Dialogue with the ghost of Amelyssan, bound to eternal service to Bhaal in her afterlife. In "Baldur's Gate 2: Throne of Bhaal", she attempted to usurp Bhaal's portfolio of murder and absorb Bhaal's essence. Now she is no more than a spectral slave.
